headline: Enormous red tape and always behind competitors
pros:
1) Talented, kind coworkers
2) Working hours
3) Benefits
4) Good for someone who starts career or retires soon
cons:
This is no longer company I was hired for couple years ago. Everything has changed after Legg's acquisition. Few things to point out: 

1) Management - these are usually analysts that suddenly become managers. You will not find out why, but these are usually people who do politics behind the scenes and make themselves visible without actually doing any impact. They usually do not posses social skills and empathy or any sort of management skills. 

2) Old technology - innovative solutions are killed because no one (including IT) wants to take responsibility or risk if something goes wrong

3) Lack of support from IT - they basically do not care if you face any software issues and cannot perform basic daily tasks. At the same time, you are not allowed to solve those issues on your own (even if something is quick and easy), because they will not grant you admin rights

4) No chance for promotion - you can perform very well for years but at the and you will be told there is no budged for promotions or someone did better than you

5) The responsibility is usually pushed on associates, sometimes they are left alone and told they have to figure out on they own.

6) They will be talking how awesome they are but they always miles behind main competitors

7) Do not think because that can put you in troubles. Your job is to DELIVER.

headline: Proud Firm Has Seen Better Days
pros: I cherished many colleagues at Franklin Templeton. The firm is filled with very smart people, with much integrity across the board. Investment professionals take their fiduciary responsibilities seriously. Also, working there was a great learning experience. Of course, the benefits are excellent, and there is stability in working for a fortune 500 type company.
cons: Morale is low. Franklin missed the ETF boom, and is losing assets to index managers and other low cost providers. So, assets and revenues are moving backwards. My sense is that take-home pay is moving backwards for most folks as well, which is tough, as the firm is based in high-rent San Francisco area. Every year employees get asked to do even more with less. Many employees are discouraged, and would rather work for a company with more growth.

cons: The management styles can vary greatly from department to department, which is not always a bad thing, but leaves for some groups to love working here and some to hate it.  I would say that the firm has historically not been a front runner in innovation, but I have seen this start to change in the time that I've been at the firm.

There are few opportunities for promotion because the Edinburgh office is not expanding (and I don't think the company as a whole is, either).

Many people have worked there so long that they are institutionalised and don't realise that the Franklin Templeton way may not be the only way and certainly isn't best practice (this includes middle and senior managers). Many of the people I worked with had to be on calls out of hours to Asia, India or the USA. The excitement wears off this very quickly.

headline: It's really just OK.  Good benefits, other than pay, but it is so outdated.

cons:
Everything from the management styles down to the appliances is outdated, like 1980s outdated.  The outside of the buildings look prestigious but inside you have cube farms with bland bare white walls and tan carpet that's better suited for an overseas call center.  The appliances in the break rooms became obsolete when Reagan was in office. The office chairs may have been bought at a liquidation sale when Circuit City went out of business.

Management and culture match the motif.  It's very much a "don't rock the boat" environment. Innovation is not valued nor encouraged. What little does change is at an incredibly slow pace.  Next year they may upgrade to MS Office 2013...

Nobody hangs out after work.  It's very much a punch the clock environment.  Some groups try to organize quarterly fun activities but those events make watching paint dry seem like a rave.

If you are looking for a clear career path, feedback on your performance, or mentorship look somewhere else.  Management strongly believes in career "self-guidance." Its very much a pull yourself up by the boot straps, make it on your own environment.  That style fits the 80s appliances nicely.

Base pay is notoriously below average especially for the Bay Area location.

headline: Mismanaged by managers and supervisors that have not learned or earned their position
pros: Pre-2000 when Sir John Templeton was still alive, employees were treated like human beings. Work life was well balanced and positive. People leaders actually earned their positions and paved the way to a prosperous future.
cons: Now, those that have paved the way have either retired or told to leave by being granted roles that would discourage them to stay on. End result- when the mass lay offs occurred, supervisors that got the position because of connections are left crying- exposed for not knowing their role, even having been in the company for over 15 years. There's a great handful of these arrogant rude leaders that only act tough as a false facade- terrorizing those that know the business, discouraging them to even think of advancing in their current position. Sabotaging their performance appraisals, and making the most loyal of all staff feel lower than dirt. When Sir John passed away, a lot of the humanity and spirit died with him. So too have the loyal customers passed on. These leaders think it's some kind of farce. Instead of solving problems and leading, they make mischief and tomfoolery on their staff, lowering their self esteem and quality of work. Firing left and right just to cover and sweep things under the carpet. Now the company is a circus, shuffling current staff to cover work of a different department. Retention of knowledge is lower therefore more mistakes and fund losses. Vacations can't even be planned- we have a skeleton crew!  The specialists are only assuming on conjecture- not knowing the departments from which they are writing procedures and policies for. The total focus is lost. And when someone does something spectacular to save the company all they are given is a $5 Tim Horton's card. While staff from the US are given a plane ticket ,accommodations and acknowledged for their contributions and loyalty with a spectacular celebration. Shame!
